DataElementConcept.preferredName: Concomitant Medication Domain Prior Therapy Administered
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to concomitant medication administration._Prior action or administration of therapeutic agents that produced an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process._The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Drug and/or Immunotherapy

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Drug and/or Immunotherapy
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Originally, therapeutic administration of serum or gamma globulin containing preformed antibodies produced by another individual; currently, immunotherapy includes nonspecific systemic stimulation, adjuvants, active specific immunotherapy, and adoptive immunotherapy.  New forms of immunotherapy include the use of monoclonal antibodies.  This approach has been widely adopted by cancer specialists, often in cases which fail to respond to other treatment.  Immunotherapy aims to boost immune system function, as with the administration of interferons and interleukin-2, or to attack cancerous cells directly, as with the injection of monoclonal antibodies.  Various immunotherapeutic techniques have also been employed among AIDS patients.  In addition, a number of alternative medical practices are claimed to enhance immune function, and various over-the-counter substances (e.g., goldenseal, lysine have gained popularity for this supposed property.

Concepts.definition: Originally, therapeutic administration of serum or gamma globulin containing preformed antibodies produced by another individual; currently, immunotherapy includes nonspecific systemic stimulation, adjuvants, active specific immunotherapy, and adoptive immunotherapy.  New forms of immunotherapy include the use of monoclonal antibodies.  This approach has been widely adopted by cancer specialists, often in cases which fail to respond to other treatment.  Immunotherapy aims to boost immune system function, as with the administration of interferons and interleukin-2, or to attack cancerous cells directly, as with the injection of monoclonal antibodies.  Various immunotherapeutic techniques have also been employed among AIDS patients.  In addition, a number of alternative medical practices are claimed to enhance immune function, and various over-the-counter substances (e.g., goldenseal, lysine have gained popularity for this supposed property.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Radiation Therapy

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Radiation Therapy
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.

Concepts.definition: Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Surgical procedure

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Surgical procedure
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.

Concepts.definition: A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Prophylaxis NOS (MedDRA)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure to replace diseased or pathologic bone marrow with transplanted healthy bone marrow stem cells.

Concepts.definition: A procedure to replace diseased or pathologic bone marrow with transplanted healthy bone marrow stem cells.
